definitions.sensetop: it is/seems odd that…it is odd to do something

examples.text: They're very odd people.
There's something odd about that man.
That painting looks very odd.
a teenage girl with **rather odd** hair
After a while she noticed something quite odd.
When we got inside something struck me as odd.
It's an odd little movie.
It seems odd that nobody noticed anything wrong.
It's **most odd that** *(= very odd that)* she hasn't written.
The **odd thing** was that he didn't recognize me.
It's odd to think I will never see her again.
examples.contextForm: it is odd to do something

examples.text: I didn't think it odd at the time.
I find it odd that she takes so long to do that job.
She had the oddest feeling that he was avoiding her.

definitions.definition: strange or unusual in the way mentioned

examples.text: an odd-looking house
an odd-sounding name

definitions.definition: that cannot be divided exactly by the number two

examples.text: 1, 3, 5 and 7 are odd numbers.
Each section may have an odd or even number of players.

definitions.definition: happening or appearing occasionally; not happening often

examples.text: He makes the odd mistake—nothing too serious.

definitions.definition: of no particular type or size; various

examples.text: decorations made of odd scraps of paper

definitions.definition: not with the pair or set that it belongs to; not matching

examples.text: You're wearing odd socks!
Could I see you when you've got an **odd moment**?

definitions.definition: approximately or a little more than the number mentioned

examples.text: How old is she—seventy odd?
He's worked there for twenty-odd years.

definitions.definition: a person or thing that is different from others or does not fit easily into a group or set

examples.text: At school he was always the odd man out.
Dog, cat, horse, shoe—which is the odd one out?

definitions.definition: a person who is slightly strange or crazy

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the numerical sense): from Old Norse odda-, found in combinations such as odda-mathr ‘third or odd man’, from oddi ‘angle’.
